node.title: Why "It's a Wonderful Life" continues to stand the test of time
node.description: "It's a Wonderful Life" debuted 75 years ago — but it wasn't an instant commercial success.

node.title: El Salvador frees 3 women imprisoned for abortions
node.description: The women had been sentenced to 30 years in prison under the nation's strict anti-abortion laws after suffering obstetric emergencies, activists said.

node.title: Queen Elizabeth's Christmas message touches on love and loss
node.description: "Although it's a time of great happiness and good cheer for many, Christmas can be hard for those who have lost loved ones," the queen said. "This year, especially, I understand why."

node.title: Special tradition behind Boston Common's Christmas tree
node.description: Nova Scotia sent Boston a Christmas tree as a gesture of thanks in 1918 — a gift repeated in 1971 and every year since.

node.title: Duchess of Cambridge performs moving Christmas piano song
node.description: The royal wowed a Christmas Eve audience with a beautiful piano performance alongside singer-songwriter Tom Walker.

node.title: COVID outbreak hits another Florida-based cruise ship
node.description: Carnival Freedom cruise was denied entry to Bonaire and Aruba after an undisclosed number of passengers and crew tested positive.

node.title: Dozens reported dead in Myanmar massacre
node.description: A witness who spoke to the Associated Press said the bodies were tied up with rope and set on fire.

node.title: Pope, in Christmas message, prays for unity and an end to pandemic
node.description: In his Christmas Day address, Pope Francis urged urge health care for all, vaccines for the poor and dialogue to resolve the world's conflicts.

node.title: Christmas Powerball prize could reach $400 million
node.description: It's the third time this year that the prize has reached the $400 million mark.

node.title: 3 Hong Kong universities remove Tiananmen Square monuments
node.description: Government officials have been quelling dissent in Hong Kong ever since Beijing imposed a national security law.

node.title: How to watch NASA's James Webb Space Telescope launch on Christmas
node.description: NASA and its international partners are launching the most expensive science probe ever built — a $10 billion effort to explore the origins of the universe.

node.title: Essential workers slammed again as Omicron variant spreads
node.description: COVID-19 is again hitting nurses, flight crews and other frontline staff. "We don't have enough hands," one grocery worker says.

node.title: Flooding and snow hit the West as the South expects record highs
node.description: National Weather Service warns of hazardous travel conditions for some areas over the holiday weekend.

node.title: Audi gives losing "Wheel of Fortune" contestant a new car
node.description: Outrage ensued after Charlene Rubush lost out on a new Audi despite guessing correctly. So the automaker saved the day.

node.title: Washington Football's Deshazor Everett hospitalized after car crash that killed woman
node.description: "Our thoughts and prayers are with everyone who has been affected by this tragedy," the team said in statement.

node.title: COVID antiviral pills could be game changer—if you can find them
node.description: Supplies of antiviral pills from Pfizer initially will be scarce, with some states getting only 100 courses of treatment.

node.title: Photos: White House Christmas decorations
node.description: The White House is lit up for the holiday season and decorated to reflect the theme "Gifts from the Heart."

node.title: Bidens to spend Christmas with family at the White House
node.description: Instead of celebrating in Delaware, as they usually do, the Bidens will spend this Christmas at the White House, at the request of their grandchildren.

node.title: Comet Leonard lights up the night sky this Christmas
node.description: Leonard is the most anticipated and dazzling comet of the year.

node.title: U.S. to lift the temporary travel restrictions on 8 African countries
node.description: The travel restrictions were imposed in late November on eight countries.

node.title: Carly Pearce on her "mind-blowing year"
node.description: Country singer Carly Pearce's acclaimed album "29: Written in Stone" was named one of Rolling Stone magazine's top albums of the year.

node.title: Girl killed when L.A. police open fire on suspect in crowded store
node.description: Police said the girl was in a dressing room with her mother when a bullet came through the wall.

node.title: Search to resume for time capsule on old Robert E. Lee monument site
node.description: A box workers in Richmond, Virginia found that was thought to be the famed time capsule actually wasn't, so the search is to begin anew.

node.title: Extraordinary challenges ahead for Webb space telescope
node.description: The world's largest space telescope, folded up to fit in a rocket, will have to unfurl itself like a high-tech origami — and that's just the beginning.

node.title: Chris Martin says Coldplay will stop making new music as a band in 2025
node.description: "Our last proper record will come out in 2025, and I think after that we will only tour," he said.

node.title: Religious pilgrimages on the rebound after pandemic put them on hold
node.description: The coronavirus pandemic forced the Catholic Church to cancel its annual pilgrimage in 2020, but this year travelers were back.

node.title: Retail sales could reach $859 billion this holiday season
node.description: November and December sales could be up as much as 11.5% from 2020, according to the National Retail Federation.

node.title: Comedian Frank Caliendo on "The Takeout"
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, comedian Frank Caliendo talks with Major Garrett about how the divisiveness of national politics has changed comedy.

node.title: Why House Democrats are retiring or moving on before the next election
node.description: Twenty-three Democrats so far are leaving the House, compared to just 11 Republicans.

node.title: Overnight ferry inferno kills dozens, injures scores more
node.description: Many passengers jumped off and swam to shore on the river in southern Bangladesh. The vessel had 800 aboard. One official says the blaze may have started in the engine room.
